syllabus_content: Qualitative analysis of cations, anions and gases
learning_outcomes: Describe the techniques used in the preparation, separation and purification of salts by precipitation
Describe the general rules of solubility for common salts
Describe electrolysis as the conduction of electricity through an ionic compound when molten or in solution, leading to chemical changes at the electrodes
Predict the likely products of the electrolysis of molten binary ionic compounds using inert electrodes
Relate thermal stability of metal carbonates to the reactivity series
Identify redox reactions in terms of oxygen/hydrogen gain or loss and changes in oxidation state
Describe the characteristic properties of acids in reactions with bases to form salts
Describe typical transition elements as metals forming coloured compounds
Describe the differences between elements, compounds and mixtures
Calculate empirical formulae from relevant data
Calculate the percentage mass of an element in a compound
Represent energy changes by energy profile diagrams, including activation energies
Explain overall enthalpy changes in terms of the energy changes associated with breaking and making covalent bonds
Describe bond breaking as an endothermic process and bond making as an exothermic process
Describe essential conditions for corrosion (rusting) of iron and methods of prevention
Describe sacrificial protection of iron by a more reactive metal
Place specified metals in order of reactivity using given reaction evidence
Deduce order of reactivity from experimental results
Describe qualitatively the difference between strong and weak acids in terms of the extent of ionisation
Describe neutrality and relative acidity and alkalinity in terms of relative H⁺ and OH⁻ ion concentrations
Describe the meanings of the terms acid and alkali in terms of the ions they produce in aqueous solution
Describe the characteristic properties of acids in reactions with metals to form salts
Describe neutrality and relative acidity and alkalinity in terms of relative H⁺ and OH⁻ ion concentrations
Describe electrolysis as evidence for the existence of ions which are held in a lattice when solid but free to move when molten or in solution
Deduce the numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons in atoms and ions given proton and nucleon numbers
Define the term isotopes
Describe Cl₂, Br₂ and I₂ as a collection of diatomic non-metals showing displacement reactions with other halide ions
Predict properties of elements in Group 17 using the Periodic Table
Describe the use of aqueous potassium iodide in testing for oxidising agents
Define redox in terms of changes in oxidation state and identify redox reactions
Apply the concept of solution concentration to process the results of volumetric experiments and solve simple problems
Describe, using ‘dot-and-cross’ diagrams, the formation of covalent bonds between non-metallic elements
Relate the physical properties of covalent substances to their structure and bonding
Describe the use of nitrogen (from air) and hydrogen (from cracking of crude oil) in the manufacture of ammonia
Describe the effect of temperature on reaction rates and explain these effects in terms of collisions between reacting particles
Interpret data relating to the conditions used in industry for processes involving reversible reactions, e.g. the Haber Process
Define the term catalyst and describe the effect of catalysts on reaction rates
State that some chemical reactions are reversible (e.g. manufacture of ammonia) and explain their impact on achievable yield

Suggest suitable apparatus, given relevant information, for a variety of simple experiments, including drying and collection of gases (drying agents limited to calcium oxide, concentrated sulfuric acid and fused calcium chloride)
Describe Group 18 elements as mono-atomic and unreactive, important in providing an inert environment
Describe the lack of reactivity of noble gases in terms of their electronic configurations
State qualitatively the effect of molecular mass on the rate of diffusion and explain the dependence of rate of diffusion on temperature
Describe the solid, liquid and gaseous states of matter and explain their inter-conversion in terms of the kinetic particle theory and of the energy changes involved
Interpret paper chromatograms including comparison with ‘known’ samples and the use of Rf values
Interpret paper chromatograms including comparison with ‘known’ samples and the use of Rf values
Interpret paper chromatograms including comparison with ‘known’ samples and the use of Rf values
Interpret paper chromatograms including comparison with ‘known’ samples and the use of Rf values
Describe production of electrical energy from simple cells linked to the reactivity series and redox reactions
Describe electroplating of metals and state one use
Construct ionic equations for reactions occurring at electrodes during electrolysis
Describe production of electrical energy from simple cells linked to the reactivity series and redox reactions
Describe production of electrical energy from simple cells linked to the reactivity series and redox reactions
Place specified metals in order of reactivity using given reaction evidence

syllabus_content: Qualitative analysis of cations, anions and gases
learning_outcomes: Describe the use of precipitation tests to identify aqueous cations or anions through characteristic insoluble products
Describe electroplating of metals and state one use
Apply selective discharge ideas (cations, anions, concentration effects) to predict electrolysis products with inert electrodes
Describe electrolysis as the conduction of electricity through an ionic compound when molten or in solution, leading to chemical changes at the electrodes
Construct ionic equations for reactions occurring at electrodes during electrolysis
Predict the likely products of the electrolysis of aqueous electrolytes using inert or reactive electrodes
Apply selective discharge ideas (cations, anions, concentration effects) to predict electrolysis products with inert electrodes
Place specified metals in order of reactivity using given reaction evidence
Relate the reactivity series to displacement reactions that occur in aqueous solutions
